parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>Command</title><part><name>Comments</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma </value></part><part><name>Game name</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00</value></part><part><name>Game version</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Strings </value></part><part><name>GROUP1</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Converts any value into a string by placing " and " around the argument. Since Arma 3 v1.63.137891 this command will correctly escape all " inside a string:

<code>// Before the fix:
[[hint]] [[str]] "string "" string"; // "string " string" <- invalid string
[[call]] [[compile]] [[str]] "string "" string"; // ERROR
// After the fix:
[[hint]] [[str]] "string "" string"; // "string "" string" <- valid string
[[call]] [[compile]] [[str]] "string "" string"; // OK
</code>

When used on object, object debug name is returned. </value></part><part><name>DESCRIPTION</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> '''str''' value </value></part><part><name>SYNTAX</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> value: [[Anything]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[String]] </value></part><part><name>RETURNVALUE</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_s = [[str]] (2 + 3);</code>

The value of ''_s'' is the string "5" </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>a = [];
ac = 0;
[[while]] {ac < 5} [[do]] {
	ac = [[count]] a;
	a [[set]] [ac, [[format]] ["Index %1", ac]];
};
[[hintSilent]] [[str]] a;</code>

Hints all of ''["Index 0","Index 1","Index 2","Index 3","Index 4"]'' including brackets, quotes and commas. </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE2</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[toArray]], [[toString]], [[isText]], [[select]], [[count]], [[find]], [[endl]], [[format]], [[formatText]] </value></part><part><name>SEEALSO</name>=<value>

</value></part></template>

[[Category:Scripting Commands Arma 2|<template><title>uc:<template><title>PAGENAME</title></template></title></template>]]
[[Category:Scripting Commands Arma 3|<template><title>uc:<template><title>PAGENAME</title></template></title></template>]]
[[Category:Scripting Commands Take On Helicopters|<template><title>uc:<template><title>PAGENAME</title></template></title></template>]]

<comment><!-- CONTINUE Notes -->
</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on September 29, 2009 - 20:17 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Sbsmac|Sbsmac]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
When applied to a unit, this returns the variable name that was assigned to the unit in the editor.  For example, if you have created a playable unit with the name 'thePlayer' then you can use 'str player' to return "thePlayer";
</dd>
</dl>
<dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on December 5, 2014 - 20:21 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:DreadedEntity|DreadedEntity]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
If you try to [[count]] string, the added quotations marks are valid characters and will be counted.
</dd>
</dl>
<comment><!-- DISCONTINUE Notes -->
</comment>
<comment><!-- CONTINUE Notes -->
</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on July 15, 2017 - 09:59 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Killzone Kid|Killzone Kid]]</dt>
<dd class="note">If you want to make empty string with [[str]] that doesn't have any quotation marks, but is still a [[String]] you can use [[text]]: 
<code>[[str]] ""; // ""
[[count]] [[str]] ""; // 2
[[str]] [[text]] ""; //
[[count]] [[str]] [[text]] ""; // 0</code>
</dd>
</dl>
<comment><!-- DISCONTINUE Notes --></comment></root>
